Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please provide the following information: -
- How the council measure digital inclusion and its plans to improve this
- The targets Heeley Trust are held to in relation to delivery of the Sheffield Online programme
- How the council measures digital inclusion and IT literacy by ward and how to access this data
Yours faithfully,
Matthew Smith

Dear Matthew Smith,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Digital inclusion
which we received on 09/03/2021.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request, and will be
dealt with under the Freedom of Information Act.  The reference number for
your request can be found above.
The Freedom of Information Act states that we must respond to you within
20 working days, therefore, you should expect to hear a response from us
by 08/04/2021.
While we endeavour to fulfil statutory deadlines, due to the current
pandemic situation there may be delays due to resourcing shortages. We
will try to provide updates where possible.
In the meantime, if you have any queries please, contact us at the email
address below.
Thank you.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Matthew Smith,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Digital inclusion
which we received on 09/03/2021.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
1. DI is measured or reported on by each year by ONS, OfCom, Lloyds Bank
and Good Things Foundation. SCC considers all of these measures in its
assessment of digital inclusion. SCC has established a DI Taskforce,
following a city wide DI summit in Jan 2021. The taskforce met for the
first time in Feb 2021 and is defining a vision, aims and objectives
that it will consult on in due course. These will be published on the
councils website and we recommended checking the SCC website over the
coming weeks for further information.
2. SCC’s contract with Heeley Trust is for delivery of approximately 20
free online classes per week, delivered at libraries and community
centres across the city.  They are specifically promoted to our
tenants and leaseholders as they are funded by the Housing Revenue
account (HRA). The classes are delivered by a network of volunteer
Digital Champions, and they follow the ‘Learn My Way’ course (a
national digital learning app / platform). Since the first lockdown,
HT have had to change their approach.  They now deliver a range of
online support sessions to replace the in-person classes.  These
include a weekly Digital Inclusion class via Zoom, weekly ‘iTea &
Chats’, weekly classes focusing specifically on using iPads and ad hoc
‘PC Doctor’ sessions.  Heeley are also providing 1:1 telephone support
to tenants. Alongside the routine classes, HT also work with us to
train a number of our TARA reps to be the ‘digital champion’ for their
area, and those DCs get ongoing support from both us and HT.
3. SCC is currently investigating if/how it can break down DI data at a
more granular level and is in discussion with partner organsiations
about how this might be done. SCC also expects to consult with local
groups supporting DI to see if they can help contribute to this hyper
local understanding empirically and/or qualitatively. There are other
indicators which can also be used to estimate the levels of DI such as
deprivation indices.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by either writing to the above address or by emailing
[2][Sheffield City Council request email]. Internal review requests should be submitted
within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[3]www.ico.org.uk for further details.
Kind Regards,

Sheffield, S1 1UJ
